New Council
Needs Blood
Cooperation
Closer coordination of student
council and student
.body affairs
plus a variety of assemblies will be
the primary goals of the student
council this year, Gene Zemsky,
S.C. prexy, disclosed this week.

EDDIE SEMLER, leading scorer in the State last year, will be a
mainstay of the team.
Parking on the campus and
•
the bolstering of commlanity campaigns will also play major roles
in the council's agenda.
A committee headed by Wendell
Smith is in the process of engaging diversified assemblies. Noteworthy speakers, some representing the Democratic and Republican parties, will be on hand
The first of these political assemblies is scheduled for Oct. 24, at
4 p.m. in Levering.
Much emphasis will be placed
on seasonal assemblies including
a dual presentation oethe Hopkins
and Goucher Glee Clubs at Christmas time.
Urges Blood-Letting
At the council meeting early
this week Zemsky urged ,an all
out participation in the Red Cross
blood drive which will take place
at Hopkins on October 15. He also
announced that chest x-rays this
year surpassed any previous year
with a number well over 1500.
Zemsky reminded that all organizations are requested to submit a copy of their respective constitutions to the S.C.
Zemsky also stated, "All investigations of student affairs, will
be carried on in a fair and just
matter, with no preliminary condemnations."

By STEVE PASSERMAN
The pigskin part of fall will
officially arrive on the Hopkins
campus tomorrow at 2 p.m. when
the Jays clash with the Dips from
Franklin and Marshall in their initial gridiron encounter. ,
Coach Frank Burns and his
bruised squad of 38 are looking
forward to avenging a 52-7 drubbing suffered at the hands of the
Pennsylvanians last year.
"The squad has been working
out since September 8 and as a
result the boys are in fine shape,"
Burns said. The only crippling injury thus far has hit fullback Angie Fortunato, who was slated to
see much action, but has been
sidelined for a minimum of two
weeks with a shoulder separation.
Split T Offense
Basing his hopes for a winning
season on the successful combination of a veteran backfield and a
young line, Burns, along with
backfield coach MacErwin, has
been working his offensive plays
from a modified split T formation.
Bucky Myers will be at the important quarterback slot calling
the plays. Speedsters Ed Semler
and George Klemmick will fill the
left and right halfback posts respectively. A newcomer to the
Homewood gridiron will be Stan
Dorney, who is set to start at fullback.
Semler was the state college
scoring leader last year and is expected to wind up his final season
in fine style. Although late in coining out this fall, the plucky 166

"Long and Sleepless Night" Zartman And

Supplement
The printers of the 1952 Hullabaloo have assumed the responsibility for preparing and distributing the supplement, because of
production difficulties which befell last year's 'Baloo editors.
Thompson-Ellis - Hutton, publishers of the year-book, expect it
to be out in the near future, but
can give no date. It will be mailed
to all subscribers to the regular
edition of the book.
The difficulties of. the student
staff were both personal and financial. The editor of the book, I.
William Zartman, left for Denmark on a Fulbright scholarship
without preparing the supplement.
Aut Fox, co-editor of this year's
book, was unable to undertake the
preparing of the supplement.
Financially, the size of the supplement was in doubt because of
a low bank reserve. After a conference between the printer and
Dr. Kelso Morrill, director of student activities, a publishing arrangement has been worked out to
insure a smaller sized supplement.
However, there is still a possibility that the book may run in the
red.

been printed to cover spring activities, not included in the yearbook,
which is issued the first of June.

By FRANK P. L. SOMERVILLE

Reflections On Rushing
With rushing season well under way, we are tempted to
reiterate our recent prophecy that the fraternity system is
secure on the Hopkins campus only so long as it is prepared
to adjust itself to the changes that may be taking place in its
freshman audience.
These changes, we admit, may not be as severe as many of
-Us predicted in the early days of the New Plan, but the generally
disappointing turn-outs for last Saturday's stag parties is a
straw in the wind that can not be ignored even by the most
indifferent rushing chairman.
We do not mean to imply that a definite swing away from
fraternities is developing in the freshman class as a result of some
obscure New Plan influence. We are suggesting, however, that
this translation of an ideal into efficient terms, this new system
with which we are still acquainting ourselves—this New Plan,
may be attracting a new type of personality to Homewood.
If, during the next few weeks, the fraternities find that they
are meeting fewer party boys and more violinists, they must
adjust to this change. The fraternities have no choice but to
bend with the prevailing wind.
To the interested freshman we offer a word of cautious advice.
Fraternities occupy a secondary prace in the Hopkins tradition
and this is as it should be. This is not a "greek campus"; the
emphasis is upon moderation. The decision that many of you
will make on November 9 is, therefore, not as crucial as first
impressions may lead you to believe.
The necessary motives for "going fraternity" are abundantly
present, as they were in previous years. The freshman is typically a young man away from home in a challenging and some-what indifferent environment. He needs security and the fraternity offers it on the group level. His standards, still influenced
by mental pictures of the ideal "college-man", dictate that the
non-fraternity man is a social misfit.
The unique feature of the Hopkins fraternity community
is that it is a minority group. We doubt the proposition that this
is due to a high degree of selectivity on the part of the fraternities. The more likely assumption is that a great many Hopkins
students derive security from other sources or are unwilling to pay
the price, in terms of cash ond conviction, of fraternity membership. The independent is not mis-fitted, but finds himself in a large
and diversified group. We make these observations out of
• fairness to the system and the freshman because during the
ensuing weeks the advantage of propaganda will definitely lie
with the fraternities. These are considerations that must not
be overlooked by the prospective brother.
We recognize the psychological necessity for the 'fraternity
system, but are unable to reconcile its discriminatory clauses and
essentially undemocratic processes with the traditionally liberal
atmosphere of •the Hopkins. The very fact that fraternities are
a large and increasingly vital factor on the American college scene
is unmistakable evidence that there are those who disagree with
the above considerations or who tacitly choose to ignore them.
If you should choose to make the decision, by all means, make
it critically and only after all doubts have been dispelled and
all questions answered. The choice between a number of possible
fraternities is indeed a crucial one. Each of the thirteen social
fra4ernities at Hopkins is in some measure characteristically
different from its competitors. Each _represents a unique collective
personality and it is to this personality that the freshman
must relate himself, even conform, if he is to belong.

Fewster Conditions
Freshman Booters

The 1952 edition of the Jay's
soccer team, says Mentor Wilson
Fewster, seems to be rounding
into good shape.
He sees room for improvement,
but feels that they will be ready
come October 10, w hen the Jays
meet Gettysburg.
Stan Henry, Jerry Williamson,
Jim Hutchins, and Buzzy Budnitz
all appeared on last year's MasonDixon Conference selections for
honors. These four will be sparking the Jays again this year. Hutchins was last year's high scorer,
while Buzzy Budnitz was a close
runner-up. Stan Henry and Jerry
Williamson, this year's co-captains, wilt be filling in two of the
half-back positions, while Jerry
Strauss will probably be the third.
Sam Marekas, Larry Walz, Dick
Roes, Gordon Puryear, and Charlie Barroll are fighting hard to get
into the line-up at halfback.
Dick Cohn is the only fullback
returning from last year's squad.
He is expected to fill in one of the
fullback spots, while Tony Campitelli, Dave Wentz, Ken Luxenburg, and Charlie Carlson are
batting it out for the other position. Coach Fewster is also going
to try Gordon Puryear and Charlie
Barroll at the fullback position.
Fewster says that both are natural
halfbacks, but have very good
kicks and might do well as fullbacks.
•

points of the team. Four out of
the five men that made up last
year's line are back with Dick
Roes who alternated at outside
left last season also on the scene.
Roes and Ali Armin from Teheran
are having a battle for the outside
left position. Billy McDowell will
probably fill the inside left slot.
Jim Hutchins last year's star
center forward will be filling this
spot once again. At inside right
will be Buzzy I3udnitz, • while
Bobby Lang will fill out the right
wing position. Off hand, Fewster

Closer coordination of student
council and student
.body affairs
plus a variety of assemblies will be
the primary goals of the student
council this year, Gene Zemsky,
S.C. prexy, disclosed this week.

EDDIE SEMLER, leading scorer in the State last year, will be a
mainstay of the team.
Parking on the campus and
•
the bolstering of commlanity campaigns will also play major roles
in the council's agenda.
A committee headed by Wendell
Smith is in the process of engaging diversified assemblies. Noteworthy speakers, some representing the Democratic and Republican parties, will be on hand
The first of these political assemblies is scheduled for Oct. 24, at
4 p.m. in Levering.
Much emphasis will be placed
on seasonal assemblies including
a dual presentation oethe Hopkins
and Goucher Glee Clubs at Christmas time.
Urges Blood-Letting
At the council meeting early
this week Zemsky urged ,an all
out participation in the Red Cross
blood drive which will take place
at Hopkins on October 15. He also
announced that chest x-rays this
year surpassed any previous year
with a number well over 1500.
Zemsky reminded that all organizations are requested to submit a copy of their respective constitutions to the S.C.
Zemsky also stated, "All investigations of student affairs, will
be carried on in a fair and just
matter, with no preliminary condemnations."

By STEVE PASSERMAN
The pigskin part of fall will
officially arrive on the Hopkins
campus tomorrow at 2 p.m. when
the Jays clash with the Dips from
Franklin and Marshall in their initial gridiron encounter. ,
Coach Frank Burns and his
bruised squad of 38 are looking
forward to avenging a 52-7 drubbing suffered at the hands of the
Pennsylvanians last year.
"The squad has been working
out since September 8 and as a
result the boys are in fine shape,"
Burns said. The only crippling injury thus far has hit fullback Angie Fortunato, who was slated to
see much action, but has been
sidelined for a minimum of two
weeks with a shoulder separation.
Split T Offense
Basing his hopes for a winning
season on the successful combination of a veteran backfield and a
young line, Burns, along with
backfield coach MacErwin, has
been working his offensive plays
from a modified split T formation.
Bucky Myers will be at the important quarterback slot calling
the plays. Speedsters Ed Semler
and George Klemmick will fill the
left and right halfback posts respectively. A newcomer to the
Homewood gridiron will be Stan
Dorney, who is set to start at fullback.
Semler was the state college
scoring leader last year and is expected to wind up his final season
in fine style. Although late in coining out this fall, the plucky 166

By FRANK P. L. SOMERVILLE

Reflections On Rushing
With rushing season well under way, we are tempted to
reiterate our recent prophecy that the fraternity system is
secure on the Hopkins campus only so long as it is prepared
to adjust itself to the changes that may be taking place in its
freshman audience.
These changes, we admit, may not be as severe as many of
-Us predicted in the early days of the New Plan, but the generally
disappointing turn-outs for last Saturday's stag parties is a
straw in the wind that can not be ignored even by the most
indifferent rushing chairman.
We do not mean to imply that a definite swing away from
fraternities is developing in the freshman class as a result of some
obscure New Plan influence. We are suggesting, however, that
this translation of an ideal into efficient terms, this new system
with which we are still acquainting ourselves—this New Plan,
may be attracting a new type of personality to Homewood.
If, during the next few weeks, the fraternities find that they
are meeting fewer party boys and more violinists, they must
adjust to this change. The fraternities have no choice but to
bend with the prevailing wind.
To the interested freshman we offer a word of cautious advice.
Fraternities occupy a secondary prace in the Hopkins tradition
and this is as it should be. This is not a "greek campus"; the
emphasis is upon moderation. The decision that many of you
will make on November 9 is, therefore, not as crucial as first
impressions may lead you to believe.
The necessary motives for "going fraternity" are abundantly
present, as they were in previous years. The freshman is typically a young man away from home in a challenging and some-what indifferent environment. He needs security and the fraternity offers it on the group level. His standards, still influenced
by mental pictures of the ideal "college-man", dictate that the
non-fraternity man is a social misfit.
The unique feature of the Hopkins fraternity community
is that it is a minority group. We doubt the proposition that this
is due to a high degree of selectivity on the part of the fraternities. The more likely assumption is that a great many Hopkins
students derive security from other sources or are unwilling to pay
the price, in terms of cash ond conviction, of fraternity membership. The independent is not mis-fitted, but finds himself in a large
and diversified group. We make these observations out of
• fairness to the system and the freshman because during the
ensuing weeks the advantage of propaganda will definitely lie
with the fraternities. These are considerations that must not
be overlooked by the prospective brother.
We recognize the psychological necessity for the 'fraternity
system, but are unable to reconcile its discriminatory clauses and
essentially undemocratic processes with the traditionally liberal
atmosphere of •the Hopkins. The very fact that fraternities are
a large and increasingly vital factor on the American college scene
is unmistakable evidence that there are those who disagree with
the above considerations or who tacitly choose to ignore them.
If you should choose to make the decision, by all means, make
it critically and only after all doubts have been dispelled and
all questions answered. The choice between a number of possible
fraternities is indeed a crucial one. Each of the thirteen social
fra4ernities at Hopkins is in some measure characteristically
different from its competitors. Each _represents a unique collective
personality and it is to this personality that the freshman
must relate himself, even conform, if he is to belong.

Fewster Conditions
Freshman Booters

The 1952 edition of the Jay's
soccer team, says Mentor Wilson
Fewster, seems to be rounding
into good shape.
He sees room for improvement,
but feels that they will be ready
come October 10, w hen the Jays
meet Gettysburg.
Stan Henry, Jerry Williamson,
Jim Hutchins, and Buzzy Budnitz
all appeared on last year's MasonDixon Conference selections for
honors. These four will be sparking the Jays again this year. Hutchins was last year's high scorer,
while Buzzy Budnitz was a close
runner-up. Stan Henry and Jerry
Williamson, this year's co-captains, wilt be filling in two of the
half-back positions, while Jerry
Strauss will probably be the third.
Sam Marekas, Larry Walz, Dick
Roes, Gordon Puryear, and Charlie Barroll are fighting hard to get
into the line-up at halfback.
Dick Cohn is the only fullback
returning from last year's squad.
He is expected to fill in one of the
fullback spots, while Tony Campitelli, Dave Wentz, Ken Luxenburg, and Charlie Carlson are
batting it out for the other position. Coach Fewster is also going
to try Gordon Puryear and Charlie
Barroll at the fullback position.
Fewster says that both are natural
halfbacks, but have very good
kicks and might do well as fullbacks.
•
Forward Line Strong
This year's forward line appears to be one of the strongest
points of the team. Four out of
the five men that made up last
year's line are back with Dick
Roes who alternated at outside
left last season also on the scene.
Roes and Ali Armin from Teheran
are having a battle for the outside
left position. Billy McDowell will
probably fill the inside left slot.
Jim Hutchins last year's star
center forward will be filling this
spot once again. At inside right
will be Buzzy I3udnitz, • while
Bobby Lang will fill out the right
wing position. Off hand, Fewster
